title: Paula Fox "The Coldest Winter" book cover square sans
content:
Not Agency, not Refrigerator, not Nomad (yes, I searched myfonts for square sans)

Any ideas?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100725041348im_/http:/typophile.com/files/coldestwinter_6002.jpg)
author: pattyfab

comments.content: Hmmm, not Bourgeois from Jonathan Barnbrook/Virus Fonts, either.

Alternatives:  
 [Stratum](http://web.archive.org/web/20100725041348/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=PRC.118813.0.0)  
 [Manifesto](http://web.archive.org/web/20100725041348/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=TY.116876.0.0)  
 [Rodchenko](http://web.archive.org/web/20100725041348/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/paratype/rodchenko-cond/?refby=typographica)
I think Refrigerator is closer than the others you cited (and by a typophile) but it lacks the funky W and R of the sample.

Maybe [Liquorstore?](http://web.archive.org/web/20100725041348/http:/www.chank.com/font_detail.php?sku=5123)

Maybe [Nicotine?](http://web.archive.org/web/20100725041348/http:/www.chank.com/font_detail.php?sku=5029)
Both nice (and have great names) but I'm really looking for an ID not a suggestion for an alternative.
We just got spanked!

No! Of course I appreciate the suggestions. I don't have a specific use for this font but was really struck by it and hoped to find out its name in case I want to purchase it later. Hoped it was from some boutique foundry one of y'all know about that I don't.

I think it might be a combo of Nicotine and Nicotine Jazz, but it's hard to tell from those small samples. Also reminds me of [www.cape-arcona.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20100725041348/http:/www.cape-arcona.com/ "www.cape-arcona.com") stuff. (Nope, close but no cigar :) It definitely looks "chank-ish" though.

Cape Arcona has some nice fonts and well priced, thanks for the tip.

I don't think the R matches either Nicotine. It's definitely a font because it's used pretty extensively on the jacket, not just for the title. The designer is a friend of a friend so I may try to find out that way.
You are correct. Not sure if it may be a different chank font, he's got some others that are similar (I think)...
Could be, but the way that site is designed I'll never find out.
Nobody else?

Patty, I checked the stuff I have collected in my Sans Guide and also scoured the two Indie Fonts books. The ones that have been mentioned were about the closest I saw too. The only other idea I had was ['Cachet'](http://web.archive.org/web/20100725041348/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/agfa/cachet/), which has the R and W, but not quite the right S, and the C isn't closed enough.

- Mike Yanega
We suck.

Not many sans serif fonts have the same WWII and industrial feel than this one.

You get to take a look inside the book on [Amazon](http://web.archive.org/web/20100725041348/http:/www.amazon.com/gp/reader/0805078061/ref=sib_dp_pt/002-3759566-7851233).

It reminds me of the lettering of fighter planes and bombers during WW2 and Korea. I can't find the URL for the site that sells those fonts, sorry... (hundreds of bookmarks and unorganized).

Edit: Nope, not quite right. See: [http://www.tlai.com/med\_des/modeling.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20100725041348/http:/www.tlai.com/med_des/modeling.html "http://www.tlai.com/med\_des/modeling.html")  
But then, these examples are from more recent lettering styles, so...?

Oh well, thanks everyone. I may try going to the horse's mouth directly.

It's a great book too... altho they stuck some superfluous photos in, no doubt to stretch it a bit.

I thought I'd got it with Lineto's Freundschaft, not even shouting range of a cigar though.  
Can't link directly to it, under the historic category.  
 [http://lineto.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20100725041348/http:/lineto.com/ "http://lineto.com/")

Tim

[http://lineto.com/The+Fonts/Categories/Historic+Fonts/Freundschaft/](http://web.archive.org/web/20100725041348/http:/lineto.com/The+Fonts/Categories/Historic+Fonts/Freundschaft/ "http://lineto.com/The+Fonts/Categories/Historic+Fonts/Freundschaft/")

you can link directly, there's always the direct link in the bottom part of the menu.

\*advertisment\* if its only a few words or even a logo (and a free project) i could give you my [octroy](http://web.archive.org/web/20100725041348/http:/www.art.ificial.ch/2005/octroy.gif), but its only a illustrator-file. its a bit more in the sovjet-direction i think.
I promise to let you all know when I find it. I've been to busy to get in touch with my friend who knows the designer.
Just discovered Nick Serman's [Plan 9](http://web.archive.org/web/20100725041348/http:/nicksherman.com/design/plan9.html) that is worth mentioning in this genre.
Any news, Patty?

Add another to the list: [Gagarin](http://web.archive.org/web/20100725041348/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=TB.116949.0.2&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=WINTER+ABSH&sampleSize=48)
horse's mouth: Jennifer Carrow
Ah, Ricardo slips in with another clue. Did you check the book jacket or do you know her?

Nah, I just did some Googling and found an image of the back cover. She also did the jacket for Paula Fox's previous memoir, _Borrowed Finery_. But I haven't been able to find anything like a website or online portfolio for this designer.
My copy (hard cover) says Jacket Design by Raquel Jaramillo. I actually know Raquel - or did awhile back - but she didn't reply to my email query.
I guess I was looking at an image of the paperback version, then. You can't tell the difference, with these damn pixels! ;-D
